awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Quantifying the Interfacial Partitioning and the Structural Modifications of Polyatomic Ions in Model Aerosol Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Environmental Chemical Science Program (ECS) of the Chemistry Division. It represents a collaboration between Professor Joshua D. Patterson of the Department of Molecular Biology and Chemistry at Christopher Newport University and Professor Arunkumar Sharma of the Physical Sciences Department at Wagner College. They use a combined experimental and computational approach to study the properties of ions containing many atoms (polyatomic ions). Ions are found in large concentrations in aerosol particles throughout the atmosphere. These ions participate in reactions that often take place in the boundary of atmospheric aerosol particles. This project aims to improve understanding of these reactions. The structures and availabilities of the ions within the boundary region of model aerosols are determined. The research is carried out by the investigators and their undergraduate students. The students who participate in the project gain experience in physical, computational, and atmospheric chemistry. The students participate in an exchange program between the two institutions and receive training in the complementary disciplines. This training broadens the undergraduate research experience and builds synergy between the computational and experimental elements of the project.

Heterogeneous reactions that occur in aerosol particles are of critical importance to the atmosphere. They are a crucial component of chemical reaction cycles linked to Arctic and Antarctic ozone loss, tropospheric ozone production, and acid rain. Despite the importance of these reactions, the ability to predict their outcomes is limited by the complexity of the environment where these reactions occur. Interfaces have unique chemical properties that cannot be described by gas or liquid properties. The preferential allocation of ions to the interface, a process not observed in liquids, is believed to have a strong impact on heterogeneous reactions. This project utilizes spectroscopic and computation methods to examine the structures of polyatomic ions. Interfacial properties (affinity, interfacial-core partitioning, and ion depth) are quantified. The approach uses reverse micelles (aqueous droplets in a non-polar liquid) as model systems for atmospheric aerosols. The quantification of the interfacial properties of polyatomic ions improves our knowledge of heterogeneous chemistry and the predictive accuracy of atmospheric chemistry models.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation-funded project (CHE-1708635), running from 2017 to 2023, embarked on an ambitious journey to explore the intricate world of atmospheric chemistry. This endeavor focused on unraveling the complexities of polyatomic ions within aerosol particles, akin to those found in sea spray. The project's innovative approach, combining experimental and computational methodologies, has yielded significant insights, furthering our understanding of the interfacial behaviors of these particles.

Our research utilized reverse micelles (RMs) as models to simulate the conditions of sea spray aerosol particles. This approach provided a controlled environment to study the interactions and structural behaviors of polyatomic ions. A cornerstone of our research was the investigation into the behavior of nitrate ions, NO3- within the interfacial region. Our findings revealed that the infrared absorption spectrum of NO3- undergoes significant changes when situated in this region, indicating modifications in bond lengths and vibrational properties. This insight is particularly valuable as it sheds light on the molecular-level interactions occurring in aerosols, enhancing our comprehension of their chemical behavior and impact on the environment.

One of our key studies explored the arrangement of water and ions in bis(2-ethylhexyl) sulfosuccinate sodium salt (AOT) reverse micelles. Through detailed molecular dynamics simulations, we discovered that Cl- ions are predominantly located within the aqueous core, whereas K+ ions exhibited a strong affinity for the interface. This finding is crucial for understanding the partitioning of ions in aerosols and has implications for the broader field of atmospheric chemistry. Another significant aspect of our research addressed the dynamics of water within reverse micelles. This study aimed to determine whether water in these conditions adheres to a two-state model (core/ interface) or a three-state model (core/intermediate/interface). Our simulations supported the three-layer model, showing that water properties progressively resemble those of bulk water as the size of the reverse micelle increases. This result not only advances our understanding of water dynamics in confined environments but also has broader implications for the study of aerosols in atmospheric chemistry.

One of the most impactful aspects of this project was its contribution to education and scientific training. The research was primarily conducted by undergraduates from various universities, providing them with hands-on learning experience and contributing to their development as the next generation of scientists. The research findings also have significant implications for climate science. An enhanced understanding of the interfacial behaviors of aerosols and their constituents like water and nitrate ions can lead to more accurate climate models. This, in turn, has the potential to inform environmental policies and strategies aimed at mitigating climate change. Finally, the project extended its reach beyond the scientific community, engaging the public through educational publications and presentations. This effort increased public awareness and understanding of the importance of atmospheric research in addressing environmental challenges.

The grant has supported a total of 19 students, including 13 women, 8 first-generation, and 5 Chicanx/Hispanic students. Of the 16 students who have graduated so far, 11 have gone on to graduate programs (Ohio State Univ. (2), Penn. State Univ. (1), Univ. of Notre Dame (1), Cornell Univ. (1), Johns Hopkins Univ. (1), Stevens Institute of Tech. (2), and CNU (1)) or medical school (2). Fifteen students have presented their research at conferences, including National ACS Meetings, regional ACS Meetings, Sigma Xi/Hampton Roads ACS meetings. The primary investigators have given 5 invited talks (Sonoma State University, Reed College, California Polytechnic State University, Haverford College, College of William & Mary, Wagner College), as well as presented our research at 12 conferences from international to local in scope, including 2 Gordon Research Conferences, 2 meetings of the Inter-American Photochemical Society, 4 National American Chemical Society (ACS) Meetings, and 2 regional ACS meetings.

In summary, the NSF-funded project has made substantial contributions to our understanding of the interfacial properties and behaviors of polyatomic ions in aerosol particles. The blend of innovative research methods, collaborative efforts, and educational initiatives advanced the field of atmospheric chemistry and had broader impacts through contributions to climate science, public engagement, and the training of future scientists. These achievements underscore the vital role of fundamental research in addressing environmental challenges and enhancing societal knowledge.
